#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=( ( DMP ) )
#Text=You can see a listing of other
#Text=Wikipedian residencies here .
#Text=There have been several , but still less than ten , and each situation has been unique .
#Text=I ca n't really speak to any specific future collaborations being worked on , as I am not privy to those negotiations .
#Text=However , I will say more generally that these relationships are only going to become more common .
#Text=Wikimedians and chapters around the world have been in touch with various institutions interested in working with us .

#Text=I saw and met many of these people firsthand at GLAMcamp NYC , which was attended by dozens of excited representatives from cultural institutions attracted by the prospect of a relationship with Wikipedia and just as many incredibly motivated Wikimedians who are involved in reaching out to these institutions .
#Text=The National Archives is reaching out to other crowdsourced projects for scanning and transcription .

#Text=During a program on citizen archivists , Jessica Zelt ( North American Bird Phenology Program ) , Matthew Knutzen ( New York Public Library ) , and Darla Adams ( Ancestry.com ) are shown with moderator Meredith Stewart ( National Archives ) .
#Text=Image : National Archives and Records Administration .
#Text=( ( WN ) ) Are there other — non-Wikimedia — opportunities online you feel the National Archives should look for ?
#Text=( ( DMP ) )

#Text=The goal of cataloging , describing , digitizing , and transcribing the entire holdings of the National Archives is an impossible one using traditional methods and within traditional budget constraints .
#Text=Cultural institutions need to engage the interested public to become active partners in preserving cultural heritage , rather than simply consumers .
#Text=The work with Wikimedia is an important aspect of that new thinking , but there are all sorts of allied projects out there that would also make good partners .

#Text=This includes similar crowdsourced projects for scanning and transcription , which the National Archives is already seeking out , as well as other specialized groups interested in digital history or particular topic areas .
#Text=( ( WN ) ) How have your experiences — both in school and in Wikipedia — prepared you for this job ?
#Text=( ( DMP ) ) I am a history geek and an archivist-in-training .

#Text=In my life off of Wikipedia , I have an undergraduate history degree , have worked in library/archive settings before , and am currently pursuing master 's degrees in both history and library science ( archives management ) .
#Text=I think these real-life experiences in their field are one of the main reasons that the National Archives was comfortable letting me on to their staff .
#Text=I hope to be able to relate to the people and the practices here on a higher level than the average Wikimedian .
#Text=I believe strongly in the work and the mission of the National Archives completely apart from how it syncs up with Wikipedia .
#Text=As a Wikimedian , I have been deeply immersed in various aspects of the project for many years now .
#Text=I first started back in 2004 , and have been an administrator since 2005 .

#Text=Along the way , I served as arbitrator , CheckUser , oversighter , and OTRSer , gaining a useful perspective on some of the project 's inner workings and ( for lack of a better word ) governance .
#Text=I 've also done outreach to real people as a Wikipedia Campus Ambassador for university students in Boston .
#Text=I am cross-project Wikimedian , having also been very involved in Wiktionary over the years , where I am also an administrator .
#Text=I have written content ranging from dictionary definitions of modern colloquialisms to articles on Chilean revolutionaries .
#Text=But , most importantly , I hope that my familiarity with the culture and practices of Wikimedians will help facilitate this National Archives collaboration .
